Fucking stupid

The fact that so many people are nothing wrong with this title is a little disturbing. If ST posted “17 Chinese people have COVID-19, none have eaten any bats” and the shoe was on the other foot, would this not outrage you? The title is the first thing people see and react to - if it assumes the worst about your race or group you identify you, is it not xenophobic? And no, @charleslovespainting this is not “mincing their words”. There was a way to phrase this. The information presented would have been in no way diluted and distorted by having a BETTER HEADER. Secondly, the existence of such a header and article is a reflection of how ugly our society is because there is a need for such information to be cleared up. Demand creates supply basic econs. FACT: We are racist! And we need to do something about this entrenched racism instead of bickering about whether it exists: it does. Thirdly, come on guys can we please do better? Hello! Can wake up or not? Stop demonising a whole group of people. They are in a foreign country, far away from their families who they are probably worried sick for back home. Can show some sympathy or not?

answers.text: @clarytolen you don't win points here for form, only for the function of your arguments in defending your position. So far you're doing pretty good.

@quarkycacti there's no point elaborating if you don't even understand a simple reasoning. The context of the news article concerns the speculation that B was infected by A which prompted ST to publish research to find out if that was the case. If that's the case, then it's straight forward. If not, supporting fact must be present to support the conclusion such as B was infected by C. However, a natural and to-the-point conclusion will say whether B was really infected by A, such as the headline leaving the supporting fact in the main body. Fact is a fact, direct as is. Indirect message leads to more speculations for people who likes to take things out of context such as people who don't read the full article.
@charleslovespainting also great that you assume I’m doing nothing. I’m a volunteer... really you wanna go there?

@charleslovespainting your perspectives are one thing, your inability to say anything except “mince your words” and feeble points are another. go to school boy stop fighting on the internet. Mince words so much your brain kena mince
@charleslovespainting learn how to spell “imaginary”. If you think racism if imaginary you better open tor eyes and look in the mirror you clown.

@clarytolen "he sounds like a broken recorder it really is cb period 😂think he got dropped on the head or something" - Hypocrisy at its best. By strongly advocating for the rights of the minority race, you automatically think it's okay to be less sensitive to people who have different perspectives. Now go on and parade your moral superiority before this crisis ends and pinning the blame on imaginery issues so you feel better about yourself while contributing nothing to improve their conditions.
@quarkycacti he sounds like a broken recorder it really is cb period😂 think he got dropped on the head or something
@clarytolen thanks haha what to do as long as some people get it hais

@charleslovespainting huh? No you didn’t. You just kept repeating the same point bro. I’m asking you to elaborate and you either give me the definition, which is not what I’m asking. Or simply state that the excluding some words from the title completely ruins the whole article. I’m asking you why? If you’re “legitimate” reason is just saying the same thing over and over - you’re reason isn’t very strong is it. And i’ve asked you several follow up questions as well. Comprehensions have multiple questions and you’ve only (barely) answered one with very little PEEL (point explanation elaboration link). Sorry sir but if you took my English class you would fail. Jia you okay!

@quarkycacti I have indeed answered your question on how you have altered the facts in the headline by excluding important information. It is quite clear that either 1) you lack proper comprehension skills 2) you read selectively based on what interests you. If you need your answer, you can reread what I replied before this.

@charleslovespainting more importantly: the larger picture is why was such an assumption made in the first place? speculation as to whether the author aimed to reflect the unfortunate prejudice of society or perhaps their own naivety aside, why was there a need to put it in as a “by the way”. Your concern about the existence of facts is commendable - so how about the fact that such stereotypes are the actual distortion of facts and generalisation of an entire group of people?

@charleslovespainting and hypothetical title question aside, if there was a way to phrase this with more sensitivity and maintain al the facts - is that wrong? You never answered my previous questions on how editing WITHOUT ANY OMISSION OF INFORMATION = your favourite phrase “mincing words”. Being direct doesn’t have to mean being insensitive right? And also what’s so wrong with including a few extra words - if the printer isn’t running out of ink and al info is included, why not right?

@charleslovespainting I have read the article. You’re repeated mentions of subtracting any information are puzzling because I never mentioned any exclusion of facts. So if it was in the article, just not in the title - are you saying that equates to excluding or distorting information? How? it’s still there for people to read, if anything in just a smaller font.

@quarkycacti it seems like you've you not read the news article at all except the headline because you've failed to realise the context of the news article. The news article addresses speculations that the FWs have passed the virus to the DWs, not who they got infected by. How they got infected is merely a supporting factual data to support the main idea that the DWs were not infected by the FWs. By subtracting either FWs and DWs from the equation, you've denied the info and minced the words. How can you still say that you convey the same meaning? I have no problem with sensitivity, but it should not be done in a way that distorts the facts based on the context of the article.

@charleslovespainting I don’t refer to the definition, I’m asking you to explain how changing the title alters the facts? Even if it’s mentioned again in the article itself? there are multiple ways to phrase a fact without changing its meaning. “TITLE: 17 Maids in Singapore have COVID-19. Many FDWs have been infected by their employers. In a report with, ... in response to question posed by public that ... his response was “none were infected by ...” “ I have used the exact same information in the title. I haven’t denied any info or excluded it. By your way of thinking, isn’t paraphrasing in any way or form (even if maintaining all pieces of information), misconstruing the writing? So editing shouldn’t be allowed? That’s a bit extreme. Why is editing being conflated to omission of information? Why is the ability to be sensitive have to be at odds with portraying correct information? Could you not do both?

@quarkycacti you can easily Google the definition of what I meant by "mincing journalism" since I did not change its meaning. As for the second part, facts precedes opinions, the title should not be changed if someone feels that it is insensitive. How would you change the fact that no dw were infected by fw?

@quarkycacti you say the title is the first thing people see and react to, and yet you start your reply to me by assuming my race and gender. So sensitivity matter less to you in this case now because I don't get publicity from it. You say you're not afraid to talk about racism because you have openly admitted that you're a racist. That doesn't give you any rights to be less wrong just because you've admitted it beforehand. I did not advocate a more professional or sensitive title, the title introduces the main body, not the other way round. I did not deem who's right or who's wrong, I merely offer my perspective and pointed out some facts. Your replies tend to be tangential without trying to refute most of my arguments. It's clear you're here just to repeat your opinions because you and your friends are just upset by subjective experiences and thus being extra sensitive to things especially by taking them out of context. I did not label you as a SJW because I didn't like you, but because of your hypocrisy in generalising everyone as racist by default just because the FWs are a minority and working in a disadvantaged position in our country.
@quarkycacti thank you! and don’t bother with that troll lol

@charleslovespainting my point is, it could have been done through a lens of class and not resort to racial stereotypes. If you would like to elaborate and explain what you mean by “mincing journalism” rather than just repeating it, I would love to talk. I’m genuinely curious why you think changing the title would infringe on the rest of the story.

@charleslovespainting bro are you Filipino? or Filipina? I bring this up because I have friends who are and are really upset by this. I’m not afraid to talk about racism - seeing from how I openly agreed and admitted that we are. I’m glad you are too. What I fail to understand is why you keep talking about “mincing journalism” by having a more professional and sensitive title. if journalistIc integrity is entirely based upon that then why even wrote the rest of the body? You bring up ego but you’re the one here going through every single comment and pointing out who you deem to be right and wrong. If you want to have a conversation, start listening instead of mansplaining and labelling people you don’t like as social justice warriors.

@quarkycacti The fact is we believe there's nothing wrong with the headline because it objectively summarises the nature of the content addressed in the rest of the news article. ST were not the perpetuator of the speculation between fw and dw, instead, it acts as an impartial reporter of facts involving the speculation according to what happened and what it has gathered from its research without subjective inputs. With regards to your example "17 Chinese people have covid-19, none have eaten any bats", it would not be offensive if it is within the scope of the journalism and research. That is to say the context of the news article involves the objective reporting of the claim between the infected Chinese persons and their consumption of bats. However, if ST's research and report of that figure is nothing related to the consumption of bats such that they got from another person, but the 'none got it from bats' were an insinuation by ST as a form of subjective input, then it will be offensive because the news examines nothing about the relationship between the both. Tell me: how do you get upset over a fact? By thinking of another way to phrase the headline, you're mincing words as you find a less related synonym to replace the original word or distorting the information by excluding/inlcuding words. The existence of this header is a reflection of how ignorant and close-minded we are. Doing better to stop racism is not about avoiding the topic that may be sensitive and even more so, by announcing we are racist by default without any context or specific basis is racist in itself. It insinuates how they are of a lesser race and we are more superior so we are immediately racist. It speaks of how hypocritical you are - a social justice warrior who aims to correct a wrong at whoever disagrees with them so that you can validate your own ego. Instead, we should stop seeing the differences among us and have an open mind to integrate them as our own without judgement of their name, culture, custom or way of life.

answers.text: @quarkycacti she has explicitly expressed her strong disapproval to underlying subtext that the headline of the news article reflect; which is the disrecpectful assumption of the fw and dw. It doesn't take a rocket scientist to figure this out, just some comprehension skills. However, she has taken the idea of the news article out of context by interpreting it based on her subjective feelings and her underlying understanding of the subtext behind it - even though that should not be the case since the news article merely reports facts based on the scope of its report, which in this case, addresses the speculation of the virus spread between fw and dw. Hence, the headline. By clarifying what she's upset about, the discussion can then move forward in the right context.
@charleslovespainting bro why are you telling her what she’s upset about? are you some sort of telepath because that’s really impressive
@coachtristankoh :;)
@coachtristankoh @2d.patoodie it’s okay as long as we get it. Doesnt matter if some dont
@2d.patoodie you are so right
@2d.patoodie yas yes yep

@2d.patoodie @2d.patoodie you are upset about the ignorance of the people who stereotyped the fw and dw. These people based these stereotypes and made a claim on them. These are the facts. The news outlet collects evidence on the claim and reports these facts based on their findings.  The headline represent this report.

@2d.patoodie  certainly it matters, but that's not the point of the article, isn't it? The headline is set based on the facts in the article which addresses about the assumption on the stereotyping of the fw and dw. As such, it is objective to use a headline in that manner because the headline represents the content. Facts are facts. The news reports what is, not what should be, or should not be.
@charleslovespainting how about the ignorance of the greater society on the stereotyping of fw and dw, what suddenly that matters less issit

@2d.patoodie headlines are not for attention grabbing purposes, they are tactics employed by pseudo journalism by news outlet like CNN, FOX news etc and they do it to manipulate readers. The question you should be asking is the ignorance of the greater society in speculating and spreading the assumption in the first place. The news merely reports the findings on this assumption in a factual manner.

@charleslovespainting listen, headlines serve a purpose of attracting attention. The point, is that the tone of the headline, is disrespectful, and its subtext should not be condoned or spread. The point is that we know the blatant ignorance behind the poor phrasing and we’re upset about it.

@2d.patoodie The headline is not independent from the article, instead, it is derived from the main article. By being ignorant to the greater context of the article, people on this comment section has reacted out of ignorance because they take the meaning of the article out of context and only respond to what they want to see.

@2d.patoodie  The headline is a summary and main idea of the article while the supporting details are found in the main body. By only focusing on the headline without considering the greater context of the article, you have taken the main idea of the article out of context and  misinterpreted the headline based on your subjective perspective that the FWs are treated unfairly by many Singaporeans. However, the tone of the headline merely implies what the body addresses; whether the claim made by the speculation is true. Based on the contact tracing and the facts that is presently available, that was not the case. Hence, the headline. True journalism should not mince words and reports based on facts.

@charleslovespainting i understand the practical perspective you’re adopting here, however, you must also understand that Domestic Workers and Migrant workers already face discrimination and stereotyping by a vast majority of Singaporean society. The comment section of this post is not reacting out of ignorance toward the greater context of this article, we are reacting to the sheer lack of empathy and disrespect that this headline suggests. You need to remember that as a news article, the headline is what sets the tone of the point. Based on this tone, disrespect and stereotyping is implied. So no, i do not agree with you that our reaction to this post is a reflection of ignorance, we just know the underlying subtext behind it.

@2d.patoodie  You need to understand that the majority of the people were concerned with the spread of the virus, and it has nothing to do with the foreign workers. However, it is natural for people to be concerned when speculative messages about the FWs and the maids began spreading after the news about the spike in dormitory cases broke out. I do agree with the point on how ignorant we are and this post and its comment section is a good example. The misinformations and fear spiralled out of control because we were all ignorant. Most of the people on this comment section didn't even bother to read the article before passing judgement on it. They easily believe what they read and don't think deeply beyond the surface.
@2d.patoodie amen sis

@charleslovespainting however the point is that the fact that this is even a headline really reflects on the xenophobia present in our society as a whole and how ignorance is still very very visible amongst us
@charleslovespainting aight, yeah I vibe with that

@2d.patoodie the study wasn't done because of our assumptions, but because of contact tracing. However, to be addressing the speculations together with the results of the contact tracing speaks about how irresponsible we are. While the initial concerns were understandable, the speculations were mostly carried out irresponsibly with the intent to deliberately arouse fear and manipulate or misinform the public.
@charleslovespainting sir, if we needed a study on it...what does that say about us....
@2d.patoodie exactly, patoodie.
@charleslovespainting from our greater society, charles.
@2d.patoodie where did the assumptions come from? The article merely addresses those assumptions, thus the headline.

text: Context is important here. This stemmed from an interview with K Shanmugam, where a reporter (from Zaobao) asked the minister for his view on the suspicion that some people have - that foreign workers may have passed it on to maids. The minister said that the data does not support this conclusion at all and said that he will ask for the data (i.e. this figure of 17) to be released. Hence this headline is in fact a very to-the-point rebuttal to those who continue to insinuate that foreign workers may have passed it on to maids. It is should not be seen as trying to propagate the perception, but instead to precisely counter it head-on with factual data.

Or if you had bothered to look up K Shanmugam's Fb page, you will see he uploaded a video recording of the interview on 18/04, which was what I talked about in my initial comment. But anyway, feel free to continue to think whatever you want, I'm not here to win you over.
